author: Egal Correspondent
text:
The government on Monday opposed a petition filed by BJP leader Subramanian Swamy in the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of penal provisions pertaining to hate speech, saying “this is not a public interest litigation but a private interest litigation.”

In a hearing before a Bench of Justices Anil R. Dave and Adarsh Kumar Goel, Solicitor-General Ranjit Kumar submitted that an FIR under Section 153-A of the Indian Penal Code (hate speech) had been registered against Dr. Swamy and the current petition before the apex court was “belated” and should be dismissed.

Dr. Swamy vehemently protested Mr. Kumar’s submissions, saying he was misrepresenting the issue and the petition was a constitutional challenge. “This provision has a chilling effect on my freedom to speech and expression. I am questioning its constitutionality,” Dr. Swamy said, objecting to the Solicitor-General’s portrayal of his case. Both men were also seen engaged in a brief but heated exchange in the court.

The Bench suggested to Dr. Swamy to amend his petition and go to the High Court concerned.
title: Centre opposes Swamy’s plea
